com.github.fge.lambdas

Class Chainer<N,T extends N,C extends Chainer<N,T,C>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.fge.lambdas.Chainer<N,T,C>
  • Type Parameters:
    N - parameter type of the non throwing interface
    T - parameter type of the throwing interface
    C - parameter type of the chainer
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BiConsumerChainer, BiFunctionChainer, BinaryOperatorChainer, ComparatorChainer, ConsumerChainer, DoubleBinaryOperatorChainer, DoubleConsumerChainer, DoubleFunctionChainer, DoublePredicateChainer, DoubleSupplierChainer, DoubleToIntFunctionChainer, DoubleToLongFunctionChainer, DoubleUnaryOperatorChainer, FunctionChainer, IntBinaryOperatorChainer, IntConsumerChainer, IntFunctionChainer, IntPredicateChainer, IntSupplierChainer, IntToDoubleFunctionChainer, IntToLongFunctionChainer, IntUnaryOperatorChainer, LongBinaryOperatorChainer, LongConsumerChainer, LongFunctionChainer, LongPredicateChainer, LongSupplierChainer, LongToDoubleFunctionChainer, LongToIntFunctionChainer, LongUnaryOperatorChainer, ObjDoubleConsumerChainer, ObjIntConsumerChainer, ObjLongConsumerChainer, PredicateChainer, SupplierChainer, ToDoubleFunctionChainer, ToIntFunctionChainer, ToLongFunctionChainer, UnaryOperatorChainer

    public abstract class Chainer<N,T extends N,C extends Chainer<N,T,C>>
extends Object
    Base class for chaining throwing interfaces

    If you want to add your own implementation of a chainer, extend this class and make it implement the throwing version of the interface. The default set by this package is to wrap the exception into a ThrownByLambdaException when an exception is thrown.

    Since all throwing instances extend the non throwing instances by default, this means you can use an instance of a chain as a non throwing instance; for example:

    final ToLongFunction<Path> = Throwing.function(Files::size).orReturn(OL);
    See Also:
    Throwing

      • orThrow

        public abstract <E extends RuntimeException> T orThrow(Class<E> exclass)
        Rethrow the exception using a custom (unchecked!) exception class if this throwing instance fails

        Your custom exception class must have a constructor accepting a single Throwable as an argument.

        The original exception thrown will be the cause of the generated exception.

        All instances of Error or RuntimeException thrown by the instance are thrown as is.

        Type Parameters:
        E - type parameter of the exception class
        Parameters:
        exclass - the exception class
        Returns:
        a throwing instance

      • fallbackTo

        public abstract N fallbackTo(N fallback)
        Fall back to a non throwing instance if this instance fails
        Parameters:
        fallback - the fallback instance
        Returns:
        a non throwing instance
